awd_titl_txt: Norwich Scholarship for Service program FY2018 - FY2023
awd_abstract_narration:
Norwich University, a designated National Center of Academic Excellence in Cyber Defense Education and Digital Forensics, proposes to continue and expand its participation in the CyberCorps(R): Scholarship for Service (SFS) program to prepare highly-qualified cybersecurity professionals for entry into the government workforce. Norwich SFS students develop a thorough commitment to a multi-disciplinary perspective on computer security, with awareness on integrating technology with human factors. This is done within a program that emphasizes internships and activities in the academic year. The program's strong mentoring component promotes a cooperative culture that scholars can leverage as they transition into the workplace. The SFS program funds projects that address cybersecurity education and workforce development, including funding to award scholarships to students in cybersecurity. In return for their scholarships, recipients will work after graduation for a Federal, State, Local, or Tribal Government organization in a position related to Cybersecurity for a period equal to the length of the scholarship.

As the Nation's oldest private military college, Norwich graduates have served to address threats for nearly 200 years. Many threats facing American society today, come in the form of cybercrime and cyberterrorism. The project addresses these new threats of the cyber-realm through the following strategies: providing pathways for students wishing to serve the nation in cybersecurity; fostering a culture of exploration and examination of the cyber-realm, with a focus on misuse and mitigation strategies; improving academic research and experiential learning opportunities and promoting publication; and fostering relationships with government to increase internship and employment opportunities. The project plans improving the participation of women, underrepresented minorities, and veterans; furthering undergraduate research opportunities to establish a science of cybersecurity; and coordinating outreach activities led by SFS students to increase interest in cybersecurity and promote public engagement.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report

This report provides a summary of Norwich University’s award #1754014 entitled “Norwich Scholarship for Service Program FY2018-FY2023”. In 2018, this grant was awarded for a five-year period to support 20 undergraduate scholars in their junior and senior years of college. These students enrolled in the Computer Security and Information Assurance (CSIA) Major, with concentrations in Digital Forensics (DF) and/or Information Assurance Management (IAM). 2 additional students were rolled over from our prior award (2012-2017, #1241592) and received an additional year of support from this grant, and a final student was supported for a single semester bringing the actual number of students supported to 23.

Intellectual Merit (IM) and Broader Impacts (BI) were achieved by meeting 5 goals, and through mentoring non-SFS institutions, and creating curricular innovations. These (IM, BI) will be summarised below.

Intellectual Merit

 “Create and improve existing links with Government for improving internship and employment rates” – this award was successful in placing students in relevant service. 10 entered approved positions in Federal/State/Local/Tribal/FFRDC, 12 include those with conditional offers, undergoing background checks, those applying in earnest but yet to receive an offer, and those in a repayment stage. 7 have completed the commitment phase, 6 of whom are still in approved (Government) positions.

“Foster a culture of exploration and examination of the cyber-realm, with a focus on misuse and mitigation strategies” – Students participated in an academic Cybersecurity conference in their first scholarship year and disseminated topics of interest within peer-groups such as campus clubs and societies.

“Improve academic research and experiential learning opportunities afforded to undergraduate Cybersecurity students with a view to publication of research” – All SFS students enrolled in 2 x 3cr undergraduate research classes in their senior year. Norwich partnered with the Department of Defense Cyber Institutes (bringing together the six senior military colleges in the United States) to create a new home for undergraduate Cybersecurity research. In April 2022 Norwich hosted the first peer-reviewed conference, Cybersecurity Research in Undergraduate Programs (CyRUP), in Northfield, Vermont. It was hosted at the Citadel, Charleston, SC in April 2023, and will be located at Virginia Tech, Blacksburg, Virginia, in 2024. Through this endeavour, 6 x students published peer-reviewed manuscripts (including 1 x awarded best paper at the Citadel), 2 gave presentations of their work, and a further student submitted a poster.

Curricular Innovations – Prior SFS students undertook certifications that we were able to incorporate into the classroom environment for all to take. For example, our Digital forensics program now incorporates Exterro’s and Cellebrite’s offerings as part of an academic program to demonstrate competency. Python language is now a freshman class, laying the groundwork for later AI/Machine Learning modules. Additional clubs have sprung up on campus post-pandemic, helped on by strong student leadership from prior SFS students, including a local chapter of Women in Cybersecurity (WiCyS), the local Cybersecurity Research in Undergraduate Programs (CyRUP) lab, “1819” for hackathons and competitions, and NUCIT for Cyber training to improve hands-on skills.

Broader Impact

“Engender outreach and dissemination activities to the service of the nation in cyber, furthering education and inclusion of the general populace” – The original intent was to undertake a major outreach each year (such as a booth at an event targeting underrepresented populations), and local outreach. We found we had a much greater impact upon local rather than national outreach. We attended WiCyS 2019 and hosted a booth to share Cyber opportunities with conference attendees. The conference was geared towards those who were already undergraduates seeking MS opportunities. Recruit Military in 2020 (Virtual) only garnered two conversations about Cybersecurity. We focused our efforts on more local opportunities; SFS scholars served in areas including Cyber Camp (“GenCyber”) counselors over the years, “Day of Cyber” points of contact during school visits to campus, and supporting a local Esports club providing much encouragement and expertise to junior and senior high school students. In doing so, we reached about 140 school students through Cybercamps, and about 50 through campus visits.

“Further refine student recruitment and increase the number of awards to better serve underrepresented populations seeking employment in the Government sector” – We met our goal of recruiting a greater percentage of underrepresented students than in Norwich’s prior award; which, coincidentally, was a greater percentage than in both the Norwich student body and in the State of Vermont.

“Mentoring non-SFS Institutions” – Successes at summer GenCyber camps allowed faculty at Norwich to disseminate lessons learnt at bi-annual GenCyber meetings. In Fall 2019, research faculty from Norwich were invited to speak at the Council of Independent Colleges conference, a great portion of the discussion was dedicated to mentoring SFS scholars, and thoughts for entering the program. Furthermore, via the Cyber Institutes, colleagues have been sharing efforts made by the Senior Military Consortia at Center of Academic Excellence conferences.
